sections.content: DNA, or deoxyribonucleic acid, is the molecule that contains the genetic instructions for life. It is often called the 'blueprint of life' because it holds the information that determines an organism's traits. In this lesson, we will explore DNA's structure, its role in protein synthesis, and its critical importance to living organisms. 🧬
sections.title: Introduction to DNA

sections.content: DNA is structured as a double helix, resembling a twisted ladder. Each strand consists of nucleotides, which are made up of three components: a phosphate group, a sugar molecule (deoxyribose), and a nitrogenous base. The four nitrogenous bases in DNA are adenine (A), thymine (T), cytosine (C), and guanine (G). Base pairing occurs specifically: adenine pairs with thymine (A-T), and cytosine pairs with guanine (C-G). The sugar-phosphate backbone forms the sides of the ladder, while the paired bases form the rungs.
sections.title: The Structure of DNA

sections.content: DNA serves as an instruction manual for building and maintaining an organism. It contains the genetic code that determines traits like eye color and height. DNA is integral to protein synthesis, which involves transcription (creating messenger RNA from DNA) and translation (assembling proteins from mRNA). Proteins are vital for life—they transport molecules, catalyze reactions, and provide structural support, all based on the genetic instructions in DNA.
sections.title: The Function of DNA

sections.content: DNA is essential for inheritance, passing genetic information from one generation to the next, and ensuring the continuity of life through cell division and growth. Mutations in DNA can result in genetic disorders but also contribute to evolution by introducing new traits. Understanding DNA enables scientific advancements, including medical research, forensic science, and genetic engineering.
sections.title: The Importance of DNA

sections.content: DNA is a double-helix molecule composed of nucleotides, with a sugar-phosphate backbone and nitrogenous base pairs (A-T and C-G). It stores genetic information and guides the synthesis of proteins, which are crucial for life functions. DNA plays a key role in inheritance, growth, and evolution, and understanding it drives progress in medicine, science, and technology.
